format: A data frame with 1,000 observations on the following 13 variables.

parameters.premie: Whether the birth was classified as premature (premie) or full-term.
parameters.habit: Status of the mother as a nonsmoker or a smoker.
parameters.gained: Weight gained by mother during pregnancy in pounds.
parameters.visits: Number of hospital visits during pregnancy.
parameters.whitemom: Whether mom is white or ⁠not white⁠.
parameters.sex: Sex of the baby, female or male.
parameters.weight: Weight of the baby at birth in pounds.
parameters.lowbirthweight: Whether baby was classified as low birthweight (low) or not (⁠not low⁠).
parameters.marital: Whether mother is married or ⁠not married⁠ at birth.

description:
Description
Every year, the US releases to the public a large dataset containing
information on births recorded in the country. This dataset has been of
interest to medical researchers who are studying the relation between habits
and practices of expectant mothers and the birth of their children. This is a
random sample of 1,000 cases from the dataset released in 2014.
title: US births
reference:
United States Department of Health and Human Services.
Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.
National Center for Health Statistics.
Natality Detail File, 2014 United States.
Inter-university Consortium for Political and Social Research, 2016-10-07.
doi:10.3886/ICPSR36461.v1.
